Proceeds of War

OSINT Challenge; part of Cultural Confusion

Proceeds of War

Spoiler alert: challenge solution ahead

Another guide on how to solve an OSINT challenge, again from Bellingcat.
I started this challenge when it came out, but I never really finished the challenge. Today however, I gave it another go and I solved this challenge!

Description of the challenge

Figure One displays the image which is present with the challenge. The challenge text is the following:

Solving this challenge

First, I downloaded the image and looked through the metadata, as I always do, but no useful information was obtained.

Then, instead of searching by the events in the text, I reverse-image searched the picture seen in the challenge (see figure 1). As it happens, the exact image is listed here.

The stock image came with a brief description. Here, the date and place are listed, and we can assume this picture was taken when the daggers were in an exhibition.

Following this new information, I googled "Lviv chinese dagger". The AI Overview, not always useful, suggested an article that mentions the SBU together with these daggers. I followed the source and it redirected me to the Babel (in Cyrillic) website.

You can read this about how the SBU detained Chinese daggers. I was fairly certain the Babel article is related to the particular daggers in the challenge because a lot of information matches the description information of the challenge. For example, Platar, the organization that “owns” these artworks is owned by two wealthy Ukrainians. Also, it mentions the exhibition that took place in Lviv, where we know the knives were exhibited.

Getting closer

By this point, we gathered a lot of information. We know that the daggers were exhibited in Lviv, and that they are owned by an organization called Platar. The owner of Platar (at least, the one most prominently mentioned in the article) is called Serhiy Taruta. More information is listed, such as the supposed destination of the artworks. Crucially, however, the nationality of the dark-web seller of the art is not mentioned.

Failed attempts at finding the seller

Before I jump to the right solution, I want to be clear that I was stuck here for a couple of hours. Here's some not so fruitful approaches I took first:

  • Googled for "Taruta" and "dark web";
  • Googled on "Taruta" and "SBU";
  • Used Yandex to search for the above items. Also, I resorted to Googling these items in Cyrillic, but to no avail.

How I finally found the answer

I decided to take a step back. I needed to keep it simpler, broaden my searches. I decided it would be worth a try to see if there was a connection between "Platar" and "SBU". So that's what I searched for. "Platar" AND "SBU" initially gave the same search results as searching for "Taruta" and "SBU", namely a bunch of articles that were near copies of the Babel article. But then, on the second Google page, there was a Spanish article. This caught my attention, as there was no apparent link between the Chinese daggers and Spain.

Visiting that page it became clear that this article had the answer to the challenge. This article starts with a journalist describing he talked to a man with a "Northern Spanish" accent about the Chinese treasure as described in the challenge. Further down in the article, one can see an image of the dagger that can be seen in Bellingcat's image of the challenge. Also, the background regarding the artworks matches the Bellingcat article; in short, I was sure that the Spanish journalists were talking to the alleged seller of the art.

And because the seller had a Northern Spanish accent, I masterly deduced that the seller must be Spanish. Lo and behold, this turned out to be the answer!

Conclusion

This challenge was a fun one, albeit not terribly complicated. Did I take the easiest route? Probably not - I could have googled the key events given in the story (namely that the art was detained in 2023) and I could have skipped reverse-searching the image that was provided. However, I wanted to make sure I wouldn't fall into a trap of researching a different bunch of art that was detained in 2023 and having to restart the search all over again.

To focus on Taruta might also have given the answer, but because this man is quite the public figure with arguably a questionable history, which was unhelpful.

Thanks for reading and I hope that you liked this post!
